fields.title: Pan Am Path West
fields.description:
Pan Am Path West

Starting at the Claireville Reservoir in the west end of the city, the Pan Am Path follows the Humber River Trail towards the Waterfront / Martin Goodman Trail.

Humber River Trail

This portion of the Pan Am Path is a paved 9.3 kilometer trail primarily used for hiking, walking, trail running, and road biking and is accessible year-round.

The trail is best known for a corridor of over 60 different animal species, from migratory birds, ducks, turtles to sport fish like trout, pike and salon. Spring and fall fish migration is a popular site at the Old Mill Bridge.

The Humber River has been recognized by its designation in 1999 as a Canadian Heritage River

Access Points

Claireville Dam

Humber Arboretum (Accessible, Parking, Washrooms)

Albion (Accessible, Parking)

Scarlett Mills Park (Accessible)

Centennial Park

James Gardens (Accessible, Parking, Washrooms)

Old Mill (Accessible, Parking, Washrooms)

On Road Connections

St. Phillips Stairs (Albion Rd. & Cruckshank Park

Resources

Link to Download Pan Am Path Map PDF

Link to City of Toronto Map West

City of Toronto Cycling Map

fields.title: Pan Am Path Central
fields.description:
Pan Am Central Path

Continuing from Sheldon Lookout Park, the Pan Am Path crosses the Waterfront / Martin Goodman Trail to the Lower Don River.

Waterfront / Martin Goodman Trail

Toronto's Waterfront Trail is divided into three sections: Etobicoke (west), Toronto (central), and Scarborough (east) based on the City of Etobicoke.

Trail surface is largely asphalted, routed along quiet residential streets. One stretch of Trail (2Km to Royal York to Park Lawn) follows Lake Shore Blvd. - a busy road with parking on both sides - cyclists should use caution. Toronto - Asphalt mostly off-road, but with many street crossings in central area. 

In Sunnyside Park area, asphalt path for cyclists and in-line skaters and boardwalk for pedestrians.

Information provided by the Waterfront Trail website.

Access Points

Sheldon Lookout Park (accessible, parking)

Sunnyside Park (washrooms, accessible, parking)

Exhibition Place (accessible, parking)

Queens Quay (accessible)

Resources

Link to Download Pan Am Path Map PDF

Link to City of Toronto West Map

City of Toronto Cycling Map

fields.title: Pan Am Path East
fields.description:
Pan Am Path East

At the Lower Don River, the Pan Am Path continues North and transfers to the Hydro Corridor Trail in the East end of the city. The trail follows the corridor to Highland Creek and Waterfront/Martin Goodman Trail where it ends at the shore of Lake Ontario, just a few minutes south of Rouge Park.

Lower Don Trail

The Lower Don Trail contributes a 2.5 kilometre section of the Pan Am Path for pedestrians and cyclists that runs from Queen Street, along the Don River to Pottery Road. 

The Don Valley is home to the iconic Evergreen Brickworks and a wide array of plant and animal species. Revitalization of sensitive natural habitat is ongoing.

Access Points

Evergreen Brickworks (Parking, Accessible, Washrooms)

Gatineau Corridor Trail

Approximately seven (7) kilometres of the Gatineau Hydro Corridor Trail has been built and three (3) kilometres upgraded as part of federal and provincial infrastructure funding programs.

The existing Gatineau Hydro Corridor Trail runs easterly from Victoria Park Avenue to Orton Park Road and continues again from Conlins Road to Meadowvale Road.

Access Points

Pharmacy Avenue (Accessible, parking)

Jack Goodland Park (Accessible, parking, Washrooms)

Thompson Memorial Park (Accessible, parking, Washrooms)

On Road Connections

Alder Rd. stairs to Pharmacy Ave. (5 km)

Jack Goodland Park to Marcos Blvd. (1.75 km)

Orton Park to Lawrence Ave. (3 km)

Highland Creek Trail

This portion of the Pan Am Path follows the Highland Creek to the Kingston overpass, then on to Rouge Beach Park.

Access Points

Morningside Park (Parking)

Colonel Danforth Park (Parking, Accessible, Washrooms)

East Point Park (Parking, Accessible, Washrooms)

Waterfront / Martin Goodman Trail East

From Highland Creek Trail, the Pan Am Path then leads back onto the Waterfront Trail to Rouge Beach Park.

Access Points

Rouge Beach Park (Parking, Accessible, Washrooms)

Resources

Link to Download Pan Am Path Map PDF

Link to City of Toronto Map West

fields.title: Love Letter to the Great Lakes
Embassy of Imagination - Cape Dorset Youth Mural - Coronation Park
fields.content: Avatittinnik Kamatsiarniq is a legacy public mural created by Inuit youth artists from Kinngait (Cape Dorset, NU) on Toronto's waterfront. Embassy of Imagination is an arts initiative for you in Kinngait. Parallel to this project, photo and video documentation of Avatittinnik Kamatsiarniq will be presented at the Art Gallery of Ontario as part of the group exhibition of Canadian Art, Every.Now.Then: Reframing Nationhood, June 29-January 21, 2018.

fields.content: Artists Dan Bergeron + Gabe Spectre will be completing the second wall of their KGO mural project, a 14 storey tall mural in Scarborough depicting how the natural and built worlds coincide.

fields.title: Resurge - Old Mill Station
fields.content:
Illuminating 13,500+ years of Indigenous peoples history on Turtle Island. Across 10 time points this work shows their cosmology, mapping their place within the Universe and its beginnings, with light and dark showing their world linked to the underworld (Underwater World) and spirit world (Sky World) by Philip Cote.


Connective water-work by top graffiti artists Jarus and KWEST draws a parallel with the resurgent power of nature, the underworld and spirit world, and the need to listen to Indigenous teachings.

Connective...

fields.title: Old Mill bridge transformed into canvas for Indigenous art
fields.content:
Artist says spirituality key to understanding Indigenous perspective

Few passengers boarding the subway at Old Mill where it crosses over Humber Park realize that the massive concrete pylons supporting the station have become a series of concrete canvases in the park below.

But walk past the station, down Old Mill Road and turn right into Humber Park, and you'll find Indigenous artist Philip Cote, perched on a scaffold, working on any one of ten murals that transform the pylons into teaching tools for Indigenous history.

Cote's circular murals depicting the Anishinaabe creation story are a public art commission for the Pan Am Path, the 80-kilometre path that will eventually link walking and cycling paths across the city.

For Cote, the murals are a chance to share Indigenous history and science, informed by a spiritual understanding — typical of Indigenous thought.

"The whole idea of this mural is a small seed that's going to get planted and it's going to go somewhere," said Cote. "It's the creation story of the Anishinaabe people, so we're talking about a different way of looking at the world."...

by Mary Wiens · CBC News | Link to full article

fields.title: How accessible is the Pan Am Path? One group is mapping the trail to find out
fields.content:
Partnership hopes to make the path more inclusive

One Toronto group is en route to making outdoor trails more accessible. AccessNow is mapping the Pan Am Path to find out how easily people with mobility devices can use the trail.

Maayan Ziv, founder of AccessNow, an advocacy organization, said that people often forget about lifestyle and recreational activities in the conversation about accessibility. This project is trying to change that.

"We're trying to look at how they can get people with disabilities and others who need access out and enjoying themselves just like everyone else," said Ziv.

A local handcyclist athlete, Anthony Lue will be taking the wheels. He's riding an off-road motorized handcycle created by a company called Icon Wheelchairs. It's outfitted with a 360-degree Google trekker camera...

by Salma Ibrahim - CBC News | Link to full article

AccessNow is mapping the Pan Am Path to find out how easily people with mobility devices can use the trail. Maayan Ziv, founder of AccessNow, an advocacy organization, said that people...

fields.title: This group is using a 360-camera to map Toronto's accessibility on the Pan Am Path
fields.content:
AccessNow would like to map parks throughout Ontario next

For Maayan Ziv, accessibility means a lot more than the availability of ramps to get into a government building or restaurant.

The 27-year-old founder of the social enterprise AccessNow, who uses a wheelchair, has turned her attention to accessibility for trails and parks.

"When we talk about accessibility, often we forget about recreational activities," she said.

"People should think of recreational areas as inclusive spaces."

Over the past few days Ziv and project suporters Anthony Lue and Jeff Adams have mapped accessibility on the 85-km Pan Am Path that runs from one side of the city to the other, in collaboration with Google Maps and wheelchair company Icon Wheelchairs. Using a modified mountain bike wheelchair with a mounted 360-degree camera, the project captures the path from all angles.

Zivsays that considering accessibility on trail systems is difficult. Some access points might not be accessible, others might not be clearly marked, and because of the natural environment there may be sudden changes in the steepness of the ground...

by Dave Hains - Metro News | Link to full article

fields.title: The 16 Coolest Secret Things To Do In Toronto
fields.content:
Pan Am Path consists of an 80-km stretch of trails that runs from Brampton all the way to the south portion of Rouge Park. The path is lined with various art installations and murals that are an ode to Toronto's nature and cultural diversity.

Read the article

fields.title: 10 Tips for a day on the Pan Am Path
fields.content:
Planning Your Day on the Path

With your decision to spend time on the Pan Am Path, you have already taken the first step towards a fun-filled day of exercise and exploration in the city. However, while we at Friends of the Pan Path encourage spontaneous trips, we think that there are 6 things you should do when planning your day on the Path.

 

 

1. Figure out your mode of transportation

The Pan Am Path stretches for 87km through various parts of the city, and is a perfect place to take a relaxing walk, rollerblade, skateboard, or ride your bicycle. You can choose any of these great choices: just make sure that you prepare ahead of time to avoid unexpected difficulties. If you’re walking or jogging, bring a comfortable pair of footwear; if you’re riding your bike, make sure it is in good condition and the wheels are properly inflated.

If you don't have a bike, you can rent (INCLUDE LINKS)

 

2. Bring a map for navigation

The Pan Am Path is comprised of many paths and roadways, and at certain points it is easy to take one wrong turn and get lost. To avoid any detours, we recommend that you bring our mobile map with you. For users who prefer to be offline, you can download a pdf copy of our map here, which can then be stored on your mobile device or printed out and kept in your pocket.

 

3. Check the weather & dress appropriately

In our city the weather can vary dramatically, so make sure that you are prepared for the conditions that await you. We recommend to bring a backpack: you can store extra clothes to put on in case it gets cold and there will be room to store the clothes you are wearing if it gets hot. Be sure to bring a poncho or umbrella in case it rains!

 

 4. Be aware of any obstacles, closures & safety concerns

While uncommon, it is possible that certain parts of the Path will be closed due to construction or inaccessible due to flooding or other adverse weather conditions. You want to be aware of these obstacles so that you can find ways around them ahead of time. (Put TRCA, Weather Network, City of Toronto Links)

Have a flashlight, blinkers on your bike, you might not see in some places becuase they aren’t lit

 

5. Have fuel for your body on hand

While there are many places to get food and water along the path, there are long stretches (particularly in the ravines) where food and water will be difficult to find. Therefore, don’t forget to bring a reusable water bottle to keep you hydrated, particularly on hot summer days. For food you can throw something light into your backpack, be it a couple of granola bars, a bag of trail mix, or a sandwich. Trust me, they will make a huge difference!

 

6. Give yourself freedom to explore

While you may start out wanting to only ride along the Path, you will most likely find yourself changing your mind in the moment. Perhaps you will want to attend one of the many events happening on the Path every month. Maybe you’d like to make a pit stop and go to one of the many great restaurants along the Path. You may find yourself wanting to explore a city neighbourhood that you’ve never been to before. Or you might just be tired, and would prefer to head back home and continue the ride another day. Either way, we recommend that you buy a sturdy U-Lock to securely park your bicycle when the opportunity to go off the trail arises. If you are using an alternative mode of transportation (like rollerblades) we recommend you bring a big-enough bag with you to store them, so you don’t have to lug them around. Finally, bring your wallet with you so that you can pay for transit and aren’t limited to coming back the way you came.

fields.title: IN-TER-PLAY
fields.content:
Partners: TO Parks and Trees Foundation

Dates: July / August 2018

Friends of the Pan Am Path present In-ter-play, a project built on a creative place making concept that encourages play for all ages.

This project aims to provide three intergenerational park structures to specially selected parks within Neighbourhood Improvement Areas along the Pan Am Path to encourage seniors and adults to participate and play.

fields.title: IN:SIGHT Rooftop Art
fields.content:
Partners: Waterfront Neighbourhood Centre, OCAD University

Dates:OCAD Proposal Deadline: May 14, 2018

Art Installation Completion: August 31st, 2018

 

IN:SIGHT ROOFTOP ART, is a community-led art design competition that will provide a one-of-a-kind opportunity to some of Toronto’s top emerging OCAD artists and designers to showcase their talent in a uniquely collaborative way.

The project will be overseen by a panel of Waterfront Neighbourhood Centre staff, local residents, community leaders, youth advocates, local academics and Toronto public art leaders.

The proposed installation will be installed in the summer of 2018 on top of the Waterfront Neighbourhood Centre and will be visible to local condos, office buildings and air traffic through the nearby city centre airport.

We are hoping to see this project as the inaugural pilot project for a longer-term partnership platform among the city’s Waterfront developers, local emerging OCAD artists and local residents, where the roof top design competition becomes an annual event.

fields.title: Bac & All Festival
fields.content:
Partners: The Bentway Conservancy

Date: August 6,, 2018

This unique event is a first ever community knowledge sharing celebration to follow the historic Caribana parade celebrations on August 6th, highlighting the historical roots of the Caribbean through a day of fellowship, workshops, food and a wind down from the Caribana parade weekend.

This is a day time event at the Bentway Site and will be open to families and people of all ages. Programming includes a variety of Caribbean history workshops by Anique Jordan, Socacize classes, food and more!

fields.title: Sustainable Cities
fields.content:
Partners: Evergreen Brickworks

Dates:  Final installation – October 31st, 2018

In a collaborative approach with Evergreen and Friends of the Pan Am Path (FOPAP), and curatorial efforts by International Street Artist, Emmanuel Jarus, we endeavour to build upon our unique abilities to transform public landscapes into thriving community spaces.

With conditional support in place from both Metrolinx and TRCA, the proposed project will involve painting two surfaces of two large concrete pillars of Bridge 81 in the east parking lot of Evergreen Brick Works. The pillars face both Bayview Ave and the Don Valley Parkway, and are viewed by 10s of thousands of commuters daily.

The project also recognizes the strength, abilities, and reach of a leading Canadian artist, Emmanuel Jarus, who has been immersed within the International Street Art realm for many years by positioning him in a curatorial role.

FOPAP and Evergreen recognize the importance of creating space for a new generation of artists, that might act as a catalyst for accomplishing amazing things.
